newsitem.title: USA: Edison cuts its annual hydropower forecast.
newsitem.headline: Edison cuts its annual hydropower forecast.

text.p: Southern California Edison Co trimmed its preliminary forecast for hydropower output this year to around 5,600 gigawatt hour (GWh) after a dry February, the company's chief hydrologist said Wednesday.
Based on early-February runoff forecasts, Edison estimated hydropower output as high as 6,500 GWh this year, compared with a long-term average of 4,700 to 4,800 GWh.
In 1996, Edison produced around 5,800 GWh of hydropower.

Tuesday, the California Department of Water Resources released an early-March forecast for April-July runoff on the San Joaquin River of 145 percent of normal levels, compared with an early-February estimate of 180 percent.
Most of Edison's hydro projects are on the San Joaquin, in the central and southern Sierra mountains.
Statewide April-July runoff was forecast at 115 percent of normal, while runoff for the entire water year (Oct 1, 1996-Sep 30, 1997) was assessed at 170 percent.
The discrepancy was attributed to the severe rainstorms which hit California in early January.
"This year the timing (of runoff) was thrown off by the warm rains that melted some snow," the Edison hydrologist noted.
Early indications are that March will also be a dry month for California, although conditions can always shift, he cautioned.
April 1 is seen as the peak date for measuring snowpack and assessing spring runoff volumes.
